exercises.title: Exercises 1.1 Linear Functions and models
exercises.p: For problems 1-6, given two points in the (q,p) plane and a value q_0:

li.p: Find the slope of the line determined by the points.
Give the equation of the line determined by the points.
Give the value of p predicted for q_0 by the line.

hint.p: Find the slope and use the point-slope form

li.p: First find the slope: m= \frac{\text{change in }p}{\text{change in }q} = \frac{17-5}{6-2}=\frac{12}{4}=3
Next we find the equation of the line. There are several ways to do this and two methods are outlined below.

Method 1: use the point-slope equation: p-p_0=m (q-q_0). We can choose either one of the points, so in this case we will find the line using the point (q_0,p_0 )=(2,5). This gives the equation p-5=3 (q-2).
Method 2: use the slope- intercept equation p=m q+b. Use (q,p)=(2,5) and m = 3 and solve for b: 5=3 (2)+b. And solving for b we have that b= -1, and hence p=3q-1
Evaluate at the given point. p(4)=3*4-1=11

solution.p: Just as in problem 1 we find the slope and then find the equation of the line.

li.p: First find the slope: m= \frac{\text{change in }p}{\text{change in }q} = \frac{5-10}{40-20}=-\frac{5}{20}=-\frac{1}{4}
Using p=m (q-q_0)+p_0 with (q_0,p_0 )=(20, 10) and m = -\frac{1}{4}, we get p=-\frac{1}{4}(q-20)+10. Solving for p we get p =-\frac{1}{4}q+15
Evaluate at the given point. p(12)=-\frac{1}{4}(12)+15=12

solution.p: Just as in problem 1 we find the slope and then find the equation of the line.

li.p: First find the slope: m= \frac{\text{change in }p}{\text{change in }q} = \frac{578-6}{273-412}=-\frac{5}{20}=-\frac{572}{139}

Using p=m (q-q_0)+p_0 with (q_0,p_0 )=(412, 6) and m = -\frac{572}{139}, we get p=-\frac{572}{139}(q-412)+6. (We can combine the constant terms â€“ the 6 and the -\frac{572}{139}*(-412), but leaving the equation in this form is acceptable.)
